Perhaps the most startling aspect of the Supreme Court opinions in McDonald v. Chicago was the dissenters' assault on District of Columbia v. Heller. Not only did Justice Stephen G. Breyer vote against extending the Second Amendment to state and local governments, he also argued forcefully and at length for overturning Heller and, therefore, for turning the Second Amendment into a practical nullity. Ominously, Justice Sonia Sotomayor joined the Breyer dissent - contradicting what she told the U.S. Senate and the American people last summer.
 
 Regarding the key issue in McDonald - whether the 14th Amendment makes the Second Amendment enforceable against state and local governments - Justice Sotomayor resolutely refused to tell the senators how she might vote. So in voting against incorporating the Second Amendment, Justice Sotomayor was not inconsistent with what she had told the Senate. But regarding Heller, her actions as a justice broke her promises from last summer.
 
 The Breyer-Sotomayor-Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissent urged that Heller be overruled and declared, "In sum, the Framers did not write the Second Amendment in order to protect a private right of armed self defense."
 
 Contrast that with her Senate testimony: "I understand the individual right fully that the Supreme Court recognized in Heller." And, "I understand how important the right to bear arms is to many, many Americans."
 
 Yet her McDonald opinion shows her "understanding" that those many, many Americans are completely wrong to think they have a meaningful individual right.
 
 To the Senate Judiciary Committee, Justice Sotomayor repeatedly averred that Heller is "settled law." The Associated Press reported that Sen. Mark Udall, Colorado Democrat, "said Sotomayor told him during a private meeting that she considers the 2008 ruling that struck down a Washington, D.C., handgun ban as settled law that would guide her decisions in future cases."
 
 So by "settled," she apparently meant "not settled; should be overturned immediately."
 
 In the McDonald case, the Breyer-Sotomayor-Ginsburg dissent recapitulated various arguments that had been made in Heller by the dissenting justices. The dissenters also said Heller should be overturned because some law-review articles had criticized Heller. If criticism by a handful of law-review articles were the criterion for overturning a precedent, almost every major Supreme Court precedent would be overruled.
 
 Besides, there also are plenty of law-journal articles that praise Heller and point out serious logical and historical errors that the anti-Second Amendment dissenters made in Heller.
 
 Another argument that Breyer-Sotomayor-Ginsburg made for getting rid of Heller pointed to a McDonald amicus brief by some legal historians. That brief discussed the 1689 English Declaration of Rights, which was enacted by Parliament after the despotic Stuart monarchs were ousted in the Glorious Revolution. The Declaration guaranteed "[t]hat the subjects which are Protestants may have arms for their defence suitable to their conditions and as allowed by law." This guarantee was an ancestor of the Second Amendment.
 
 According to the historians, the declaration didn't actually mean that Protestants (98 percent of the population) could have arms for their defense. It meant that Parliament could arm the militia.
 
 Those English parliamentarians apparently had great difficulty in straightforwardly expressing what they meant, as they forgot to say "Parliament" and "militia" in their new law about Parliament arming the militia.

 Justices Breyer and Ginsburg should be free to rail against Heller all they want. They never promised anyone that they considered Heller to be "settled law." Let me put in my two cents on this thread. The thread started IMO by raising a question for me: Can you square what Sotomayor said during the confirmation process with what she says in McDonald? I can’t do it, and I invite anyone here to try to do so for me. 
 
 I watched some of her confirmation hearings, and I thought we had some certainty when Sotomayor said she understood the individual right recognized in Heller. Of course many people were biased against her from the start, and they claimed that she would try to overturn Heller at her first opportunity. I feared she would try to do so, although no one really knew because ever since the Bork nomination candidates feel empowered to hide their beliefs from the Senate. So I watched closely as Sotomayor repeatedly assured her skeptics that she considered Heller “settled law.” Consider some of what she said: 
 
 
"I understand the individual right fully that the Supreme Court recognized in Heller," she testified. "I understand how important the right to bear arms is to many, many Americans."

 
 Justice: Impeach Sotomayor? | Richmond Times-Dispatch
 
 Now in response you may say, correctly, “understanding it” is not saying that one agrees to be bound by it. So see the following:
 
 
To the Senate Judiciary Committee, Justice Sotomayor repeatedly averred that Heller is "settled law." The Associated Press reported that Sen. Mark Udall, Colorado Democrat, "said Sotomayor told him during a private meeting that she considers the 2008 ruling that struck down a Washington, D.C., handgun ban as settled law that would guide her decisions in future cases."

 
 KOPEL: Sotomayor targets guns now - Washington Times (emphasis added)
 
 See also:
 
 
Sen. Patrick Leahy asked her, "Is it safe to say that you accept the Supreme Court's decision as establishing that the Second Amendment right is an individual right?" 
 "Yes, sir," she replied…. 

 
 Jonah Goldberg: ‘Kagan the UnBorkable’ shows why process a sham - Omaha.com
 
 And remember that her claimed respect for Heller and the individual RKBA it recognized were certainly sold to us by her ardent supporters:
 
 
"I do not see how any fair observer could regard (Sotomayor's) testimony as hostile to the Second Amendment personal right to bear arms, a right she has embraced and recognizes," he (Leahy) said.

 
 Jonah Goldberg: ‘Kagan the UnBorkable’ shows why process a sham - Omaha.com (emphasis added)
 
 (I encourage you to read this article in full. You may not agree with the conservative slant of the op ed, but ask yourself whether he is spot on about how much of a sham the nomination process has become) 
 
 These are the answers—and the spin put on them by her ardent supporters—that secured her elevation to the purple (or, in this case, the black robe). Contrast the above with what she said in McDonald (through concurrence with Justice Breyer):
 
 In sum, the Framers did not write the Second Amendment in order to protect a private right of armed self-defense. There has been, and is, no consensus that the right is, or was, “fundamental.” No broader constitutional interest or principle supports legal treatment of that right as fundamental. To the contrary, broader constitutional concerns of an institutional nature argue strongly against that treatment. McDonald v. Chicago, 561 U.S. ___ 081521, 31 (2010)
 
 Now let me say that I do not like the confirmation process we now have. Ever since Bork’s nomination fight candidates (and their handlers) have been scared to reveal what the person actually thinks. I would prefer that a nominee actually be required to answer questions that give us insight into how they will rule rather than claiming a right to hide their true views from us. But if we do keep the current system of hide-and-seek (in vain) for a nominee’s views—then the system should at least demand that when a nominee is forced to answer questions that he or she does not lie to us. 
 
 So, is it fair to say Sotomayor lied to us during the nomination process? I think it is. It’s one thing to say “I made a mistake, I now believe my earlier views were wrong, and others have convinced me that I was wrong and I have changed my mind.” But, to my knowledge, since donning the black robe Sotomayor has not claimed to have had a “road to Damascus” style epiphany that caused her to doubt the convictions she claimed during her nomination. So is there any way to say it other than she lied to gain confirmation?
 
 Elena Kagan just ended her successful evasion of Senate inquiry, and she is now a SCOTUS justice. During the confirmation process she also said the following:
 
 
"I think that Heller is settled law and Heller has decided that the Second Amendment confers such an individual right to keep and bear arms,” she said, citing a Supreme Court decision that overturned D.C.’s handgun ban.

 
 Kagan presents a test for the NRA as Senate confirmation assured - TheHill.com
 
 The $64 question now is: Has she lied to us like Sotomayor did? 
 
 I hope not, but only time will tell….
